content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays five discrete, ovoid to irregularly shaped tissue sections against a white background. These tissues are predominantly basophilic (purple), consistent with the appearance of lymph nodes. Some nodes show a subtle follicular pattern. The task is to systematically evaluate each of these lymph nodes for the presence of metastatic tumor cells.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node. The zoom is on the third lymph node from the top (bottom-left). The specific area of interest is the periphery of the node, right under the capsule. This region, containing the subcapsular sinus, is the first place metastatic cells typically lodge after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels. Therefore, it is a critical and high-yield area to scrutinize for evidence of metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the top-left lymph node. It is standard practice to carefully examine the capsule and subcapsular sinus of every lymph node, as this is the most common location for initial metastatic deposits. The selected area is at the interface between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding perinodal fat, which is a critical region to assess for any breach of the capsule by tumor cells, a finding known as extranodal extension (ENE). Any irregularity or architectural disturbance in this area warrants high-magnification review. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node on the slide to look for evidence of metastasis. The green box indicates a zoom into the third lymph node from the top (the middle one on the left). I am zooming into this dense, cellular area of the lymph node parenchyma to assess the cell population at high magnification. The key is to determine if the cells are native lymphocytes or if there are clusters of atypical, non-lymphoid cells, specifically malignant epithelial cells from the colorectal primary tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is part of the largest lymph node on the slide, located at the top. It is standard practice to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The specific location is the periphery of the node, just under the capsule. This subcapsular sinus region is the initial site where metastatic cancer cells typically deposit after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels, making it a high-yield area for screening. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is the periphery of the first lymph node (top right). Pathologists systematically examine each lymph node, often starting from the capsule and the subcapsular sinus. The subcapsular sinus is the initial site where metastatic cells, arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels, typically lodge. Therefore, this is a high-yield area to screen for early metastatic deposits before they invade the rest of the lymph node parenchyma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node. This is the first lymph node at the top right of the slide. I have zoomed into the periphery of the node because the subcapsular sinus, located just beneath the outer capsule, is the most common initial site for metastatic cells to deposit. Any subtle change in color (more pink/eosinophilic) or texture in this region at low power warrants high-power examination to rule out or confirm the presence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic examination of all submitted lymph nodes. This is the second lymph node from the top, located on the right. The selected area is within the cortex of the lymph node, which is a common site for initial metastatic deposits. I am assessing the morphology of the lymphoid follicles and looking for any atypical cell clusters that would suggest the presence of metastatic tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the lymph node located on the middle-right of the image. Specifically, I am targeting the subcapsular sinus, which is the area just beneath the outer fibrous capsule. This is a critical area to examine because metastatic tumor cells arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels first lodge and proliferate in this sinus. Additionally, even at low power, there appears to be some dark, irregular pigment in this region, which warrants closer inspection to identify its nature (e.g., tattoo ink, hemosiderin) and to ensure it is not obscuring any potential tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node on the slide to search for evidence of metastasis. The green box is located on the fifth lymph node (bottom right). The zoom is placed towards the periphery of the node, near the subcapsular sinus. This is a critical area to examine, as it is the most common initial site for metastatic tumor cells to deposit after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels. Even subtle changes in color or texture in this region warrant high-power evaluation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the fourth lymph node from the top (the one in the center-bottom). At low power, this node contains a distinct, irregular, pale pink (eosinophilic) area that stands out against the dark purple (basophilic) lymphoid tissue. This appearance is classic for metastatic carcinoma replacing the normal lymph node parenchyma, and therefore, it is the highest priority area to examine at high magnification to confirm or rule out metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the edge of the lymph node. At the bottom is the dense lymphoid parenchyma. Above it is the fibrous capsule. At the very top is perinodal adipose tissue. The key finding is located within the subcapsular sinus and extending into the surrounding fat: there is a population of atypical cells arranged in clusters and as single cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, and pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. My impression is that these are metastatic adenocarcinoma cells. This finding indicates that this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, I can clearly see the lymphoid parenchyma at the bottom of the image, composed of a dense population of small, dark lymphocytes. At the top, there is mature adipose tissue (fat cells) and fibrous connective tissue. The most significant finding is that the lymphoid tissue is breaking through the lymph node capsule and infiltrating the surrounding pericapsular fat. The infiltrating cells appear to be lymphocytes, not the atypical glandular epithelial cells expected from a colorectal adenocarcinoma metastasis. My impression is that this represents extranodal extension of lymphoid tissue, possibly due to a marked reactive process. While I do not see definitive metastatic carcinoma in this specific field, this is an abnormal finding that requires careful examination of the entire node to rule out malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area reveals a dense, monotonous sheet of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are morphologically consistent with lymphocytes. There are fine capillaries traversing the field. At the bottom right, there is a sinus-like space containing a mix of cells, including lymphocytes and some cells with more cytoplasm (likely sinus histiocytes). Importantly, I do not see any definite clusters of atypical epithelial cells, gland formation, or significant nuclear pleomorphism that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is that it represents benign lymphoid parenchyma, likely from the cortex or paracortex of the lymph node, with no evidence of malignancy in this view.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the edge of the lymph node adjacent to perinodal adipose tissue. The lymph node parenchyma shows multiple, well-defined lymphoid follicles with distinct germinal centers. This is a classic feature of reactive follicular hyperplasia, which is a benign process. I do not see any nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or other features to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this portion of the lymph node is benign and negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the edge of a lymph node. The outer fibrous capsule is visible at the top, with some perinodal adipose tissue to the far left. The underlying lymphoid tissue is densely cellular and organized into prominent lymphoid follicles, some with lighter-staining germinal centers. This architecture is characteristic of a reactive (benign) lymph node. The subcapsular sinus, just beneath the capsule, appears clear of any large, atypical epithelial cells. My impression of this specific area is that it is a reactive lymph node, and there is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this field of view.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node at the very top edge. Immediately beneath it, within the subcapsular sinus, there are clusters of atypical cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and enlarged, irregular nuclei. They appear to be forming small, poorly-defined glandular structures. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic tumor. The underlying lymphoid tissue appears dense and reactive.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals well-defined lymphoid follicles with prominent, active-appearing germinal centers. These germinal centers contain a mixed population of lymphoid cells and tingible body macrophages, which is characteristic of reactive follicular hyperplasia. The surrounding mantle zones and interfollicular areas are composed of small, mature lymphocytes. I do not see any evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands or clusters of malignant epithelial cells. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy in this particular field of view.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node at the top edge. Beneath it, the subcapsular sinus is expanded and contains a significant amount of coarse, granular, dark blue-black pigment, both extracellularly and within the cytoplasm of macrophages (siderophages or pigment-laden macrophages). This is characteristic of tattoo ink pigment, which is commonly used to mark the location of a tumor during a colonoscopy. I am meticulously scanning this area for atypical epithelial cells, which would be evidence of metastasis. In this particular field, I see the pigment and reactive lymphocytes, but I do not see any definitive malignant cells. My impression for this specific field is 'negative for malignancy', with the notable finding of tattoo pigment deposition in the subcapsular sinus.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area shows a dense and diffuse proliferation of small, round lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. There are some scattered, slightly larger cells with more open chromatin and visible nucleoli, consistent with immunoblasts or centroblasts within a reactive process. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, cohesive nests of large pleomorphic cells, or significant eosinophilic cytoplasm that would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific area is that it represents reactive lymphoid tissue, and it is negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-power view confirms my suspicion. On the left, there is a rim of residual, dense lymphoid tissue. The majority of the field is occupied by malignant glandular structures. These are back-to-back, irregularly shaped glands lined by atypical, pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, consistent with adenocarcinoma. There are also flecks of dark pigment, likely carbon ink used for marking. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma from a colorectal primary.
